How can Godâs will be hindered? (Rom 9:19). First, we must distinguish hindrance from total destruction of Godâs will. Second, we should realize that in everything Godâs will does prevail. Actually, when we speak of hindering Godâs will we are speaking from a human perspective. Godâs will is never really hindered. For example, when Jonah did not go to Nineveh as God had commanded, but fled to Tarshish (Jon 1:2â3), we may feel Godâs will was hindered. But actually, Godâs will can never be hindered or destroyed. God does all things according to his will. Godâs purpose will never be changed (Heb 6:17), for no one can hold back Godâs hand (Dan 4:35). One of the most important lessons we will ever learn from life is: humans may will to do this or that, but God determines humanityâs way and time (Eccl 3:14; 9:11ff). Therefore, we who have been called by God according to Godâs purpose should recognize Godâs will (2 Tim 1:9). Therefore, we should pray for our knowledge of Godâs will to increase (Col 1:9); we must also learn to obey and accept Godâs will (Mt 7:21; Jn 4:34; Acts 21:14). Often, we know Godâs will for us but still continue in our own ways. We fail to obey Godâs will because we are weak in the spirit and our wisdom has been clouded. Since we are often weak in the flesh, we must learn the truth and strengthen ourselves in the Spirit (Jn 7:17; Rom 7:18; 8:2). âGive us this day our daily bread.â Daily bread is our daily need. To ask God for our daily need is reasonable, but to want more than what we need is going beyond the Lordâs Prayer. Godâs relationship with us is very intimate and close, so God is more than ready to provide our daily needs. The Bible tells us we are all fed by Godâs grace (Ps 104; 1 Tim 4:4â5). God knows all the needs of our life (Mt 6:8, 32). As man, male and female, we came empty-handed and will leave empty-handed. God says, â[F]or the world and all that is in it is mineâ (Ps 50:12). Therefore, we must always receive Godâs provisions with thanksgiving. Hereâs a short list of how we can experience Godâs providence: Jesus said, â[S]eek first his kingdom and his righteousness, and all these things shall be yours as wellâ (Mt 6:33). The Bible tells us to work hard ourselves, we should not idly wait for Godâs providence. â[L]et him labor, doing honest work with his [i.e., a Christianâs] hands, so that he may be able to give to those in needâ (Eph 4:28). We should work to glorify God. If we sit idly, unbelievers will observe our lack of self-discipline. In being lazy and irresponsible, we put God to an open shame. God has chosen us so that we can glorify his name, so we should always do our work diligently. â[W]ork with your hands â¦ so that you may command the respect of outsiders, and be dependent on nobodyâ (1 Thess 4:11â12). Many times we cannot experience Godâs providence because we want more than what God provides. Often, like the widow that received prophet Elijah, God simply allows us the little bit we need to get by day after day (1 Kgs 17:8â16). If God gives us our daily needs, we should be content. The Bible exhorts, â[I]f we have food and clothing, with these we shall be contentâ (1 Tim 6:8; Prov 30:8â9). God will provide blessings for those who know how to give of themselves (2 Cor 9:6). âGive, and it will be given to youâ¦â (Lk 6:38). Jesus once said, when tempted by Satan, âMan shall not live by bread alone, but by every word that proceeds from the mouth of Godâ (Mt 4:4). If we recognize that Godâs providence is not merely physical, then we will go a long way in experiencing Godâs providence more and more. When we see Godâs spiritual providence, we will forget our seemingly insignificant material provisions. Jesus told the crowds that sought him for physical blessings, âDo not labor for the food which perishes, but for the food which endures to eternal life, which the Son of man will give to you; for on him has God the Father set his sealâ (Jn 6:27). We often toil and labor in this world for our physical blessing and comforts, but Jesus told us that there is something even more important: the eternal life that Jesus himself provides. Seek for the eternal and not the temporary. âForgive us our debts.â Our debts are our sins. God has taken pity on us in his mercy, for God loves us very much. God is willing to forgive the great debt of sin we owe to him (Mt 18:27). We know Godâs forgiveness because Jesus himself paid the price of our redemption with his blood (Acts 20:28; 1 Cor 6:20; Eph 1:14; Heb 9:15). If we have been forgiven in water baptism and by Godâs blood, why must we still ask God for forgiveness? Because we will still sin even after we are cleansed in water baptism. There are two types of sin we can recognize: first, we can sin by doing evil; second, we can sin by not doing righteousness. Both types of sin are actually two sides of the same coin, but no one can avoid any one or both of these types of sin. Even if we feel as if we are sinless because we have not done anything wrong, have we done anything good? Have we practiced Godâs righteousness? Only Jesusâ blood purifies us from all sin and forgives us of all our unrighteousness (1 Jn 1:7, 9). To abandon and leave unrighteousness is a constant struggle, even after we have believed (Rom 7:13ff). Even after we are forgiven of our past sins, we must pursue righteousness and godliness through Godâs word (2 Tim 3:15â17). âWhoever knows what is right to do and fails to do it, for him it is sinâ (Jas 4:17). We should not be content with our triumph over unrighteousness. Rather, to really triumph over sin we have to zealously do the good God prepared for us to do (Eph 2:10; Tit 2:14). One who does not do the good work he can do owes a serious debt. For example, if we do not tithe (Mt 23:23; Mal 3:8), we become debtors to God. Therefore, we should humbly ask God to forgive us our debts. Still, Godâs forgiveness does not free us from the duty of doing good (Heb 10:24). Asking God to forgive our debts is to spur us to live a life worthy of the Lord and to please him in every way: bearing fruit in every good work (Col 1:10). âAs we forgive our debtors.â This phrase relates back to our prayer for forgiveness examined above. Christ taught people that they must always learn to forgive one another, just as God forgave us (Mk 11:25â26; Mt 5:23â24). Since God forgave us our debts and sins against him, shouldnât we be able to forgive othersâ debts? Unless we bear one another, we cannot forgive our grievances against one another (Col 3:13). The Bible teaches us to confess our sins to each other and pray for each other (Jas 5:16). In love, we can overcome our differences and grievances with others, for love covers a multitude of sins (1 Pet 4:8). âDo not lead us into temptation.â This request in the Lordâs Prayer asks God to protect us from temptationâs draw. Temptation comes from within, for it is what draws us and causes us to sin (Jas 1:14). If we never encountered temptation, we would never be tempted to fall. But if we are surrounded by temptation, yet are never drawn to temptation, we will likewise never be tempted to fall. When Jesus was in the world, he was tempted in every way, yet without sin (Heb 4:15). Why? Because he was never drawn by temptation. Satan tempted Jesus with three temptations, but the Lord resisted all of Satanâs temptations. The Lord countered Satanâs temptation with Godâs word. Jesus told Satan: 1) Man does not only live on bread alone, but man also lives by every word of God; 2) Do not put the Lord to the test; 3) Serve and worship the Lord God alone. By holding onto Godâs word, Jesus triumphed over every fleshly temptation Satan attacked him with. Today, Satan still employs the same temptations he used on Jesus; Satan simply changes the form of his temptation. In dealing with temptation, we should follow Jesusâ example and equip ourselves with Godâs word. The three strategies we can learn from Jesus are: first, to set our mind on spiritual things; second, to always respect Godâs authority and position; third, to always seek to worship and serve God in everything we do. If these three things can become part of our lives, we will surely overcome Satanâs schemes. So we pray to God: do not to lead us into temptation. If we always pray for Godâs deliverance and keep ourselves aware of temptation, we will surely triumph over temptation. God is faithful, when we are tempted, he will provide a way out so that we can withstand (1 Cor 10:13). Peter tells us, â[T]he Lord knows how to rescue the godly from trialâ (2 Pet 2:9). âDeliver us from the evil one.â We should pray that God always deliver us from evil (the evil one) of this world. For example, when Paul was persecuted for preaching the gospel, he said, âSo I was rescued from the lionâs mouth. The Lord will rescue me from every evilâ¦â (2 Tim 4:17â18). King Solomon, in the book of Ecclesiastes, tells us that one of the sad things about life is the evil we will encounter in this world. The earth is often corrupted with sin and full of violence. Natural disasters can happen in quick succession. But as if natural disasters werenât enough, human beings themselves bring disaster upon humankind. We pollute the environment. We develop weapons of mass destruction. The list goes on. And as Christians, we may face the evil of trying to live a godly life in a godless age. Those who want to live godly in Jesus Christ will often suffer persecution (2 Tim 3:12). Jesus said, â[T]he world hates youâ (Jn 15:19). He also said, âIn the world you have tribulation; but be of good cheer, I have overcome the worldâ (Jn 16:33). Paul said, âBut the Lord is faithful; he will strengthen you and guard you from evilâ (2 Thess 3:3). âFor Yours is the kingdom and the power and the glory forever. Amenâ (Mt 6:9ff). (Note: Some ancient texts omit this part of the Lordâs Prayer, so it may not be in your Bible except as a footnote; cf. Lk 11:2ff.) The last part of the Lordâs prayer praises God, much like David praised God (1 Chr 29:10â13). The kingdom, authority, and glory of God lasts forever. We are all citizens of Godâs kingdom (Phil 3:20) and we will reign with Christ and God in the future (Rev 20:6; 22:5). We shall be glorified in Godâs kingdom (Heb 2:10; Rom 8:30). And we will be with the Lord forever. âAmenâ is a Hebrew saying meaning âtrueâ or âsincere.â The Greek equivalent also means âtrueâ (Rev 3:14). The word âamenâ is used to emphasize the prayerâs truth and sincerity. It is often used to ask God to âmake it soâ or to emphasize to others âmay it be so.â

ItemTitle: Heaven is such a remote idea. Why talk about something so far from reality when there are enough things in this life to worry about?
Content: Heaven is such a remote idea. Why talk about something so far from reality when there are enough things in this life to worry about? Our life on earth is not detached from our eternal destiny. Our earthly tasks reflect what we believe to be our ultimate goal. If you set your goal on something false, you will waste your entire life on meaningless pursuits. That is why you need to find out whether there is heaven. If heaven is real, then we have to orient our daily live to this goal. Belief in heaven actually makes a direct, positive impact in this life. Believers who look forward to heaven bring blessings to others because they obey Godâs command to love others as themselves. While Godâs promises may pertain to the life to come, Godâs commandments are for this life, not the afterlife. Our belief in heaven does not detract from our present responsibilities. On the contrary, it motivates us to make a difference on earth.

ItemTitle: What happened after Jesus was baptized?
Content: What happened after Jesus was baptized? As soon as Jesus was baptized, He came out of the water. At that very moment heaven was opened, and the Spirit of God descended on Jesus like a dove. Then a voice from heaven said, âThis is My beloved Son, in whom I am well pleasedâ (Mt 3:16â17).

ItemTitle: What was Jesus" body like after his resurrection?
Content: What was Jesusâ body like after his resurrection? Jesus resurrected in a spiritual body. We understand this because physical barriers no longer confined his actions. Also, the analogy between Jesusâ resurrection and Christian baptism tells us we are sown a natural body and raised a spiritual body (1 Cor 15:44). The Bible narrates the events surrounding the resurrection: âJesus came, the doors being shut, and stood in the midstâ (Jn 20:19, 26). âHe vanished out of their sightâ (Lk 24:31). However, we donât really know what type of spiritual body Jesus had. The Bible says Jesus had bones and flesh. So in some sense, he was tangible and could eat and speak like a normal person (Lk 24:39, 43). Jesusâ resurrection was not the result of an âundying spirit,â that never dies. To put Jesus in that category would mean Jesusâ body died and only his spirit resurrected. The Bible is clear that his body rose from death and transformed into a âglorious bodyâ (Phil 3:21; Acts 2:31). Unfortunately, we donât understand what type of body Jesus had really well, except that it was a spiritual body capable of being tangible with flesh and bone.

ItemTitle: Why must baptism be performed with head bowed and face downward?
Content: Why must baptism be performed with head bowed and face downward? In Romans 6:3-4, Paul states that believers are âburied with Christ through baptism into death.â We are âunited together in the likeness of His death,â so that we have the assurance that we shall also be united âin the likeness of His resurrectionâ (Rom 6:5). The manner of baptism during biblical times was in the likeness of the Lordâs death. Paul uses this physical likeness in baptism to discuss the spiritual likeness that believers carry. John 19:30 describes the physical likeness of Jesusâ death: âbowing His head, He gave up His spirit.â It is on this basis that we understand to what the physical likeness of the Lordâs death refers. In the Bible, bowing oneâs head expresses the disgrace and heaviness of sin (Ps 40:12; Lk 18:13; Job 10:15). Just as Christ died to sin once for all, we also die to sin so that sin should no longer have power over us (Rom 6:2,10). As we bow our heads and are immersed in water, our sinful self dies and is buried with Christ. As we rise from the water, we are raised with Christ and receive a new life in Him (Rom 6:4; Col 2:12).

ItemTitle: Can we experience the Holy Spirit?
Content: Can we experience the Holy Spirit? The Holy Spirit is formless and shapeless; Jesus told us the Holy Spirit cannot be seen (Jn 14:17). How then do we come to accept the existence of an invisible Holy Spirit? Jesus told us about the experience of the Spiritâs power and existence. Jesus once said, âThe wind blows where it wishes, and you hear the sound of it, but cannot tell where it comes from and where it goes. So is everyone who is born of the Spiritâ (Jn 3:8). Jesus once breathed on his disciples and said, âReceive the Holy Spiritâ (Jn 20:22). Jesusâ comments on the Spirit show that when the Holy Spirit descends on someone, they will know and feel it. Unfortunately, many evangelical Christian churches today feel the Holy Spirit comes silently when we believe, or that the Holy Spirit silently stayed with the church after Pentecost.

ItemTitle: Wasn't Jesus just a prophet or teacher?
Content: Wasnât Jesus just a prophet or teacher? Suppose someone walked up to you and said, âI am the way, the truth, and the life. I am not just a messenger of God, but God Himself! Besides me, there is no other way to heaven.â Would you take him to be just another moral teacher? Jesus taught about the kingdom of God and the right way to live. He prophesied about His death, His resurrection, as well as the destruction of the temple in Jerusalem. But He was also more than a prophet or a teacher. Buddha, Mohammed, or Confucius never claimed they were God. But those who witnessed Jesusâ life, His death, and His prophesied resurrection realized that what He claimed was true. No other prophet or teacher in the history of the world has risen from the dead. Jesus Christ is the living God. And because He is alive, we can also experience Him working in our lives today.

ItemTitle: How does Jesus" resurrection relate to his followers?
Content: How does Jesusâ resurrection relate to his followers? Jesusâ resurrection is at the heart of the gospel messageâa crucial step in Godâs redemption plan. God obviously plays a vital role in our salvation. So we should firmly follow the Bibleâs instructions on the way to salvation (1 Cor 15:1â2). If Jesus never resurrected after he died, believing in him would essentially be worthless. How can you get eternal life from someone who canât even overcome death himself? Had Jesus remained dead, we who die would perish with no hope for any life to come. So the Bible tells us Jesusâ followers would be the most pitiful of all people if Jesus never resurrected (1 Cor 15:17, 19). Resurrection doesnât just mean we live a new life or change our bad ways, but on the last day our physical body will actually resurrect or be transformed into a spiritual body (1 Cor 15:51â53; Jn 6:40).

ItemTitle: Can we completely know God through evidence of God's existence?
Content: Can we completely know God through evidence of Godâs existence? The evidence we discussed above may convince us God exists, yet we must be humbly willing to open up ourselves to the truth. Without a willingness to believe there will be no belief. A stubborn heart is difficult to convince. God is hidden and we do need to exercise faith to believe in Him. Our faith is not an unthinking blind faith in something totally absurd, however, believing in God does take a measure of humility. The Bible tells us God gives grace to the humble. The Bible says the pure in heart shall see God. We know God through revelation of Himself to us. The Bible says God calls us, not the other way around, i.e., we call God. So how do we come to a point of believing in God? God leads us to the point, whether we realize this or not. So if God is revealed by revelation of Himself, we may wonder: why hasnât God revealed Himself to me yet? Because God waits for you to take a step in his direction, then God will reveal Himself. This is why we continually emphasize: it takes some faith and openness to seek the truth and find the truth. God will not, we repeat, will not reveal Himself to someone who is stubborn in his belief there is no God. The evidence of Godâs existence is believable to those who are willing to believe; yet, it makes no sense at all to those who are not willing to make sense of it. God has given evidence of Himself so that people can seek Him, reach out to Him, and find Him (Acts 17:27), but people are often unwilling to take the first step. Humankind is only a tiny speck compared to the whole universe (Isa 40:15, 17), while God is higher than the heavens, that is, beyond all our understanding (Job 36:26; 11:7). What we now know of God is limited (1 Cor 13:12), for people will never know God by their own human wisdom. Only through Godâs revelation and pondering the evidence of creation can we press on to know Him (Hos 6:3), to truly know Him (Eph 1:17), to know more and more about Him (Col 1:9).

ItemTitle: Who is Jesus?
Content: Who is Jesus? Jesus is God Himself, the Word of life, who is from the very beginning. The Bible says the Word (Jesus) was with God, and the Word was God (Jn 1:1). The Word became flesh and was born as the man Jesus Christ, who was called the âSon of manâ (Mt 16:13). Jesus is Godâs beloved Son (Mt 3:17). He is the image of the invisible God, the firstborn over all creation. All things were created by Jesus for Jesus (Col 1:15â17). Jesus is the Savior of humankind, for He was born to the world for that very purpose (Lk 2:11â12).

ItemTitle: What is God?
Content: What is God? Since we canât see God, people often feel as if God doesnât exist. The Bible says only fools say there is no God (Ps 14:1). The reason we canât see God is because God is Spirit (Jn 4:24). But even though we donât see God, God is the source and reason of our existence, whether we recognize this fact or not (Rom 11:35â36). God is unique from other creations, which is an important distinction (Isa 40:18, 25). Never confuse the Creator with the created. God fills the universe and gives life and breath to all things living (Col 1:17â20; Acts 17:25, 28; cf. Eph 1:23). Since God is Spirit, He is not restricted to certain physical locations, like Jerusalem or some sacred temple (Acts 17:24). We might think, âIf God is everywhere then isnât God everything?â Pantheists say, âEverything is God.â But God is not everything, He fills the earth and is Spirit. As human beings, we are limited in how much we know about spiritual things. However, the Bible clearly tells us we are not God, and we ourselves experience we are not God. While we often think we control our destiny, tragedies wake us up to reality. The proud often have to be humbled by their tragedies to realize Godâs sovereignty. We do not control the future or the many events in our life. The Bible tells us Godâs hand controls life and death (Deut 32:39), which is to tell us God controls our destiny.

ItemTitle: What about infants and children?
Content: What about infants and children? Infants and children are born with sin (Ps 51:5), so they also need to be born again. The promise of baptism for the remission of sins is also given to the children (Acts 2:38-39). Children were never excluded from Godâs covenant with his people (Gen 17:9-14). Therefore, we must not forbid children from receiving salvation since the Lord Jesus Himself does not reject little children (see Lk 18:15-17). We can also see that in the early church, entire households were baptized (Acts 16:15, 32-34; 18:8; 1Cor 1:16). In the Old Testament, the entire household, including children and infants, crossed the Red Sea (Ex 10:9-10, 24; 12:31). Children and infants were not left in the land of bondage. Crossing the Red Sea prefigures the New Testament baptism (1Cor 10:1-2). So in the same way, children and infants must also be baptized to be cleanse of their sins and be released from the bondage of Satan. Children were healed of their diseases through their parentsâ faith (Mt 15:28). By the same token, children and infants may be baptized based on the faith of their parents (Jn 4:49-51). We must also keep in mind, however, that it is the grace of God and the cross of Christ, not the conscious choice of humans, that gives baptism its effect. So even if children cannot make a conscious choice to receive Godâs grace, they should not be excluded from Godâs grace.

ItemTitle: What good would Jesus" charity do for people?
Content: What good would Jesusâ charity do for people? Jesusâ charity satisfied the physical and spiritual needs of many people. The body is temporary, but the soul is eternal. What we donât see is more important than what we do see. Jesus cared for and healed the sick. He drove out demons and raised the deadâhealing people to a spiritual wholeness. Jesusâ work was done not for the sake of healing itself, but to draw people to spiritual progress and faith in him. Therefore, all the good Jesus did was mainly for the purpose of fulfilling and saving people spiritually. The following lists some of Jesusâ blessings: Peace (Lk 1:79; Mk 5:34; Lk 7:50; Jn 14:27; 16:33; Phil 4:7; Col 3:15). Freedom (Jn 8:36; Lk 13:16; Rom 8:1â2; Gal 5:1, 13; 2 Cor 3:17). Light (Jn 8:12; 9:5; 12:46; Mt 9:29â30; Jn 9:11; Eph 1:18; 5:13â14; Acts 26:18). Life (Jn 10:10, 28; 11:25â26; Lk 8:53â55; Col 3:4; Jn 5:40; 20:31; Eph 2:1, 5). Abundance (Jn 6:35; Mt 5:6; 14:20; Jn 6:27, 28; 1 Cor 10:3â4). Joy (Lk 1:47; Jn 3:29; Jn 16:22, 24; Jn 17:13; Jn 20:20; Acts 16:34; Phil 4:4). Protection (Mt 23:37; Jn 17:12, 15; 6:39; 2 Thess 3:3; 1 Thess 5:23; 1 Pet 1:5).

ItemTitle: Why would a good God allow suffering?
Content: Why would a good God allow suffering? Goodness is not equivalent to kindness, for "if goodness meant only kindness, a God who tolerated pain in his creatures when he could abolish it would not be an all-good God" (Peter Kreeft and Ronald K. Tacelli, Handbook of Christian Apologetics [Downers Grove, IL: InterVarsity Press, 1994], 140). Because His nature is perfectly good and just, however, God cannot tolerate sin. Having sinned and turned away from God, we are subject to His divine wrath. And since our souls are alienated from God, our bodies, too, are alienated and no longer under His protection. God gave humankind authority over nature (Gen 1:28), but when humanity rejected Godâs authority, we rejected the authority He gave us. Therefore we suffer both physical evil from the natural world (disease, famine, earthquakes) as well as moral evil from the sins we commit (hatred, envy, deceit). Yet the suffering of this world is only temporary for those who put their trust in God. If we believe in Jesus, one day our imperfect bodies will rise to enter into that perfect kingdom He has prepared. There, "He will wipe every tear from our eyes. There will be no more death or mourning or crying or pain" (Rev 21:4).

ItemTitle: Does becoming a member of church mean you can't associate with others?
Content: Does becoming a member of church mean you canât associate with others? We cannot live apart from the world; Jesus commanded us to go into it, and be the light of the world: âA city that is set on a hill cannot be hidden. Nor do they light a lamp and put it under a basket, but on a lampstandâ (Mt 5:14-15). The important point is not to let worldly influences dim or overshadow our light. Believers can and should associate with nonbelievers, so long as their faith in God is unaffected and their relationship with God remains the top priority. After all, He has called us to âshine before men, that they may see your good works and glorify your Father in heavenâ (Mt 5:16).

ItemTitle: Did God prepare for humankind's salvation?
Content: Did God prepare for humankindâs salvation? Yes. The Bible says God prepared salvation in Jesus Christ before the beginning of time (2 Tim 1:9). Hebrews says God spoke to his chosen people through the prophets in the past, at many times and in various ways; however, in the last days (last days may mean the era after Christ came) he spoke to us through his Son, Jesus Christ (Heb 1:1â2). The prophets searched intently and questioned within themselves when Jesus Christ would come. In fact, even angels long to look into matters related to humankindâs salvation (1 Pet 1:10, 12). We could say the salvation of humankind is like a great love storyâso interesting to watch unravel, even angels desire to look into it. Salvation is a great thing, for salvation concerns you in particular and all people in general (Lk 1:49; 2:10). Isnât it wonderful that God prepared salvation for everyone? (Lk 2:31).

ItemTitle: How do we offend the Holy Spirit? What are the consequences?
Content: How do we offend the Holy Spirit? What are the consequences? Resisting the Holy Spirit. If we harden our hearts and fail to believe in Jesus then the Holy Spirit cannot dwell with us (Prov 28:14).&nbsp; Deceiving the Holy Spirit. Sometimes, out of self-interested motives, we try to deceive God. However, God cannot be deceived. Ananias and Sapphira, two early Christian church members, died when they tried to deceive the Holy Spirit (Acts 5:3).&nbsp; Disrespecting the Holy Spirit. Believers have received so much grace and truth from the Holy Spirit. However, if after we have received Godâs grace and truth, we continue in our sins, we disrespect Jesus, Jesusâ blood, and the Holy Spirit (Heb 10:29).&nbsp; Blaspheming against the Holy Spirit. Some people call the Holy Spiritâs work and gifts the devilâs work (Mk 3:28â30). These people refer to Godâs work as Satanâs work because they are ignorant of Godâs intentions and ways. Jesus told us that a very serious mortal sin (sin which leads to death) and is not forgiven is to blaspheme against the Holy Spirit (Mt 12:31â32).&nbsp;

ItemTitle: Does the phrase "being born of the Spirit" refer to receiving the Holy Spirit?
Content: Does the phrase âbeing born of the Spiritâ refer to receiving the Holy Spirit? âJesus answered, âMost assuredly, I say to you, unless one is born of water and the Spirit, he cannot enter the kingdom of Godâ (Jn 3:5). It is clear that being born of the Spirit is essential for salvation. From other parts of the Scripture, we also see that receiving the Holy Spirit is a requisite for salvation. For example, Titus 3:5 states that we are saved by the washing of rebirth and the renewal of the Holy Spirit; in Titus 3:6 it explains that this Holy Spirit has been poured out on us generously. Similarly, Ephesians 1:13 says that believers have been marked with the seal of the promised Holy Spirit (i.e., received the promised Holy Spirit), who is a deposit guaranteeing our inheritance. So to be born of the Spirit does indeed refer to receiving the Holy Spirit, which is necessary for salvation.

ItemTitle: Why did Jesus have to die for us?
Content: Why did Jesus have to die for us? Shedding blood has long been considered a way to atone for sins. This principle of atoning for our sins by shedding blood crosses cultural and racial boundaries. The Bible is in line with this principle, saying the following: âWithout the shedding of blood there is no remissionâ (Heb 9:22). Jesus âloves us and has freed us from our sins by his bloodâ (Rev 1:5). We have been âbrought near in the blood of Christâ (Eph 2:13). We have been âjustified by His bloodâ (Rom 5:9). âWe have confidence to enter the sanctuary by the blood of Jesusâ (Heb 10:19). We overcome Satan by Jesusâ blood (Rev 12:11). Jesus, a sinless person, had to take the place of and die for every sinner in Godâs eyes. In Godâs eyes, we are all sinners, so God had to come as Jesus to die for everyone. It is the church that is covered by Jesusâ shed blood.

ItemTitle: How did Jesus deal with people?
Content: How did Jesus deal with people? Jesus was gentle and humble, full of sympathy and charity. Jesus said, âAll that the Father gives Me will come to Me, and the one who comes to Me I will by no means cast outâ (Jn 6:37). âCome to Me, all you who labor and are heavy laden, and I will give you rest â (Mt 11:28). He searched for and saved the lost (Lk 19:10). From these verses we catch a glimpse of the man Jesus was. We see Jesus rarely lost his temper, and when he did it was usually dealing with hypocrisy or some obstruction to Godâs work. Jesus seemed to especially look to the hopeless and lost to give hope and direction.

ItemTitle: Can we choose another day to celebrate Christ's birth?
Content: Can we choose another day to celebrate Christâs birth? Neither the celebration of Christmas nor Jesusâ birthday are recorded in the Bible. So at least from a biblical perspective, Christmas celebrations are not recommended or demanded. But does that mean Christmas celebrations are disapproved? Look at this from Jesusâ perspective, since it is his supposed birthday. Would you like someone celebrating your birthday if you didnât want them to? What if they wanted to celebrate it on a day you werenât even born? And what if the very origins of the day people celebrated your birthday was to honor another person who you didnât like much? Is that how we should honor Jesusâ birth? As we examined, Jesus is God. Jesus said, âBefore Abraham was, I amâ (Jn 8:58). âThe LORD possessed me at the beginning of His way, Before His works of old. â (Prov 8:22). God became flesh (1 Tim 3:16) and lived among us (Jn 1:14). Since Jesus is actually God, without beginning or end, there is no need to celebrate Christmas to honor his birth. For the most part, people only celebrate Christmas to get presents for themselves; but, Christians should give to others every day in more ways than one (i.e., in material gifts).

ItemTitle: What is the Holy Spirit?
Content: What is the Holy Spirit? The Holy Spirit is God, and God is Spirit (Jn 4:24). âNow the Lord is the Spiritâ¦â (2 Cor 3:17).

ItemTitle: The Bible states that our sins are washed away by the blood of Christ (Revelation 1:5). How can the water during baptism actually remove a person's sins?
Content: The Bible states that our sins are washed away by the blood of Christ (Revelation 1:5). How can the water during baptism actually remove a person's sins? The apostle John bears witness that blood and water flowed from Jesus' side (Jn 19:34). In 1 John 5:6, he explains that Jesus did not come by water only (here the water refers to baptism; notice water is mentioned first), but by water and blood, and that it is the Spirit who testifies. In other words, the effect of Jesus' blood, by the testimony of the Holy Spirit, is present during baptism to cleanse the sin of the person being baptized. Although the candidate's body is immersed physically in water, yet the blood of Jesus Christ cleanses his spiritual being (Heb 10:22; "washed" = immersed). The baptisms performed in the True Jesus Church, during which many have witnessed blood in the water, confirm John's explanation.

ItemTitle: Is there more than one God?
Content: Is there more than one God? There is only one God. The God we worship is the Lord of all creation, the first and the last (Isa 41:4), One who holds absolute power (Deut 32:39). There can be no other gods beside Him, because He is eternal, all-powerful, all-knowing.

ItemTitle: How was Jesus" socio-political environment like?
Content: How was Jesusâ socio-political environment like? The Jewish nation, ruled by Rome, would go through many wars and other trials. The Jewish nation would eventually go into decline. During Jesusâ time, Jewish nationals, who loved the Jewish nation and wanted to preserve Jewish religion, hoped Israel would one day be revived (Acts 1:6). Some may have taken a revolutionary stance, but the âzealotsâ are now believed not to have formed until years after Jesus died. However, even in Jesusâ time there was a tension between Jewish and pagan cultures. Many wealthy urban types went with the flow of pagan culture. However, many Jews were indignant to the encroaching pagan culture. The differences in thought and the grasping for power among the Jewish people resulted in an often chaotic, hypocritical, and deceitful social environment. Jesus once sighed, âWhen the Son of man comes, will He find really faith on earth?â (Lk 18:8). Jesus was not one to play along with the games of popular politics. From time to time, Jesus would denounce the crooked and depraved leaders of the people. Jesus saw how hard the hearts of people had become. He understood morality and righteousness was often compromised in his time. People then, much like today, were often indifferent to justice and mercy. The parable of the Good Samaritan illustrates Jesusâ concern over the peoplesâ compassion for one another and tense social relations (Lk 10:31â34). People had become self-centered and unfeeling. Jesus once told a parable illustrating the hardness of the times, saying the people were like children who complain to their friends, âWe played the flute for you, And you did not dance; We mourned to you, And you did not lament â (Mt 11:17).

ItemTitle: What blessings does the Holy Spirit give to the disciples?
Content: What blessings does the Holy Spirit give to the disciples? Giving spiritual rebirth and renewal. â[U]nless one is born of water and the Spirit, he cannot enter the kingdom of God. That which is born of the flesh is flesh, and that which is born of the Spirit is spiritâ (Jn 3:5â6; Ezek 37:14). Setting a seal of redemption on us. âIn Him you also trusted, after you heard the word of truth, the gospel of your salvation; in whom also, having believed, you were sealed with the Holy Spirit of promiseâ (Eph 1:13). â[T]he Holy Spirit of God, in whom you were sealed for the day of redemptionâ (Eph 4:30). âGod, who also has given us the Spirit as a guaranteeâ (2 Cor 5:5). Setting believers free. âFor the law of the Spirit of life in Christ Jesus has made me free from the law of sin and death â (Rom 8:2). âNow the Lord is the Spirit, and where the Spirit of the Lord is, there is libertyâ (2 Cor 3:17). Anointing believers with the Holy Spirit of truth. The Holy Spirit counsels us and gives us wisdom. â[T]he anointing which you received from him abides in youâ (1Jn 2:27). âBut the Helper, the Holy Spirit, whom the Father will send in My name, He will teach you all things, and bring to your remembrance all things that I said to youâ (Jn 14:26). âHe who is spiritual judges all thingsâ (1Cor 2:15). Strengthening us spiritually. âThat He would grant you, according to the riches of His glory, to be strengthened with might through His Spirit in the inner manâ (Eph 3:16). âIf you are reproached for the name of Christ, blessed are you, for the Spirit of glory and of God rests upon youâ (1 Pet 4:14). Having the power to testify. âBut you shall receive power when the Holy Spirit has come upon you; and you shall be witnesses to Meâ¦â (Acts 1:8). âAnd my speech and my preaching were not with persuasive words of human[1] wisdom, but in demonstration of the Spirit and of powerâ (1Cor 2:4). Having a fruitful spirituality. âBut the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, longsuffering, kindness, goodness, faithfulness, gentleness, self-control. Against such there is no lawâ (Gal 5:22â23). âbut we also who have the firstfruits of the Spirit, even we ourselves groan within ourselves, eagerly waiting for the adoptionâ¦â (Rom 8:23). Helping us reach the depths of spiritual prayer. âPraying always with all prayer and supplication in the Spiritâ (Jude 20). âPray at all times in the Spirit, with all prayer and supplicationâ (Eph 6:18). âThe Spirit Himself makes intercession for us with groanings which cannot be uttered. â (Rom 8:26). âFor if I pray in a tongue, my spirit praysâ¦â (1 Cor 14:14). Giving believers spiritual gifts. âThere are diversities of gifts, but the same Spirit. â¦ But one and the same Spirit works all these things, distributing to each one individually as He wills(1 Cor 12:4,11). Giving comfort. âThat you may abound in hope by the power of the Holy Spirit â (Rom 15:13). Sanctifying us. âBut you were washed, but you were sanctified, but you were justified in the name of the Lord Jesus and by the Spirit of our Godâ (1 Cor 6:11). Reviving our spiritual life. â[G]ive life to your mortal bodies also through his Spirit which dwells in youâ (Rom 8:11).

ItemTitle: Who should wash the feet?
Content: Who should wash the feet? The worker who administers the sacrament represents the Lord Jesus; this duty is thus generally delegated to church ministers who have been ordained to serve (such as elders, deacons, and preachers). If no ordained worker is present, however, every brother or sister who has been baptized, has received the Holy Spirit, and leads a godly life may perform the washing of feet.

ItemTitle: Is it right to speak in tongues during church service?
Content: Is it right to speak in tongues during church service? Paul writes, âYet in the church I would rather speak five words with my understanding, that I may teach others also, than ten thousand words in a tongueâ (1 Cor 14:19). Paul is referring to preaching (prophecy) in tongues, not prayer in tongues. When there is no interpreter, the speaker should keep quiet and âspeak to himself and to Godâ (1 Cor 14:28). Thus, Paul discourages preaching in tongues without interpretation but never discourages praying in tongues during service (see 1 Cor 14:39) Paul says that âGod is not the author of confusion but of peaceâ because during church service in Corinth, the members would preach in tongues even when there was no interpreter and many would speak at once (see 1 Cor 14:27-30). All this caused confusion and disorder. Prayer in tongues is directed to God and needs no interpretation (1 Cor 14:2). When everyone prays in tongues during church service, there is no confusion nor disorder. Rather, there is a spirit of unity.

ItemTitle: Where does salvation come from?
Content: Where does salvation come from? Godâs grace to all people is salvation (Titus 2:11). So we must understand salvation comes from God and is given to all people. The Bible said of John the Baptistâs ministry that prepared the way for Jesus, âAll flesh shall see the salvation of Godâ (Lk 3:6). John preached repentance from sins and was a forerunner to Jesus, who brought ultimate salvation to humankind.

ItemTitle: Who should Christians pray for?
Content: Who should Christians pray for? Christians should pray for everyone (1 Tim 2:1). More specifically, we should pray for: ourselves and our families (2 Cor 12:8â9; 2 Sam 12:16â17), the Lordâs servants (Eph 6:19â20; 2 Thess 3:1â2), brothers and sisters (Jas 5:16), the sick and demon-possessed (Jas 5:14; Mt 17:21), persecuted workers (Acts 12:5), all the saints (Eph 6:18), sinners (1 Jn 5:16), all those who are in high positions (1 Tim 2:2), and enemies (Mt 5:44). As Christians, we carry a great responsibility in our prayer life.

ItemTitle: What's significant about the effects of Jesus" resurrection?
Content: Whatâs significant about the effects of Jesusâ resurrection? God raised Jesus from the dead (Acts 2:32; 1 Cor 6:14), for Jesus is the author of life (Acts 3:15). Jesus once said, âI have power to lay it [my life] down, and I have power to take it againâ (Jn 10:18). He also said, âI am the resurrection and the lifeâ (Jn 11:25). It was impossible for death to keep its hold over Jesus (Acts 2:24). Death was swallowed up by his resurrection (Isa 25:8; 1 Cor 15:26). Eternal life was revealed through Jesus (2 Tim 1:10). These are some of the many verses that show the significance of Jesusâ resurrection lies in Jesusâ power and authority over death. Sin, which results in death, was dealt a severe blow by Jesusâ atoning death. So Jesus essentially opened up the way to eternal life.

ItemTitle: Isn't Christ the end of the law? Why should Christians today still observe the law by keeping the Sabbath?
Content: Isn?t Christ ?the end of the law?? Why should Christians today still observe the law by keeping the Sabbath? â Christ did not abolish the commandments In Romans 10:4, Paul discusses how the Jews try to establish their own righteousness by observing the law rather than submitting to Godâs righteousness. The passage teaches us that a person is justified by believing in Christ, not by keeping the law. Yet Paul is not saying that Christ did away with the law or Godâs commandments. Christ Himself stated that He did not come to abolish the law but to fulfill it (Mt 5:17-20). The Sabbath is mentioned at least 64 times in the New Testament, and in every instance it refers to the seventh day, with no intimation that it had ceased to be of binding obligation. Jesus Christ sacredly observed the seventh day and taught His followers to do the same: So He came to Nazareth, where He had been brought up. And as His custom was, He went into the synagogue on the Sabbath day, and stood up to read. (Lk 4:16) Then He went down to Capernaum, a city of Galilee, and was teaching them on the Sabbaths. (Lk 4:30-31) As this was His âcustom,â it follows that the Sabbath day found Jesus habitually in the synagogue, engaged in divine worship. He ever upheld the Sabbath and the Sabbath law. Concerning the law of God, of which the Sabbath commandment is a part, He said: For assuredly, I say to you, till heaven and earth pass, one jot or one tittle will by no means pass from the law, till all is fulfilled. (Mt 5:18) The Lord Jesus Christ is our perfect role model. He leaves us examples so that we can follow in His steps (1 Pet 2:21). â We keep the Sabbath under grace, not under the law. We do not keep the Sabbath in order to earn our own righteousness. We do it as Godâs children, out of obedience to Godâs commandments, under the grace of Jesus Christ. Remember, it is where your heart is that determines whether or not you are keeping the Sabbath under grace or under the law. For example, if you have to work on the Sabbath and cannot go to church, the Lord knows your heart and your desire to be in His temple. If you do not have to work, but instead choose to go fishing, here too, He knows your heart. We shall be given our just reward according to our heartsâ desires.

ItemTitle: How often should footwashing be performed?
Content: How often should footwashing be performed? As a sacrament, footwashing is only administered to a believer once. Mutual footwashing, however, may be conducted from time to time as a sign of love and forgiveness. All believers should follow the spiritual teachings of love, humble service, forgiveness, and purity imparted by the Lord.

ItemTitle: What's the difference between the Trinity and Oneness?
Content: Whatâs the difference between the Trinity and Oneness? Trinitarians recognize that God is one. But they believe the Godhead consists of three distinct, eternal coequal persons: the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit. The three persons are the same in substance, but distinct in subsistence. The Oneness of God means that the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit are one God and one Spirit, not three "persons."

ItemTitle: What does Jesus Christ's name mean?
Content: What does Jesus Christ's name mean? âJesusâ is an English transliteration of the Greek name for Jesus. In Hebrew, Jesus is Joshua, which means âthe Lord is the Savior.â Jesus is Godâs name (Mt 1:21; Isa 9:6), for by no other name can we be saved (Acts 4:12). Christ is not Jesusâ last name. Christ is derived from a Greek term, which means âMessiahâ or âanointed oneâ in Hebrew. Christ is a title not a name, designating the fact God anointed Jesus for a purpose. In ancient times, Hebrew kings, prophets, and priests were anointed before they were consecrated to perform their respective roles. Christ is Godâs anointed one, King of kings and Lord of lords (Rev 19:16; Jn 18:37).

ItemTitle: If Jesus is God, why was He human?
Content: If Jesus is God, why was He human? Jesus Christ came to the world to save sinners and to reveal Godâs love (1 Jn 4:9â10). Out of His great love for us, God manifested Himself as a human being in order to save us, so He may be crucified on our behalf (Phil 2:6â8). No one has ever seen God, but Jesus makes God known to us, as He is God himself (Jn 1:18). Today, we can be saved by believing in Jesus Christ (Acts 16:30â31).

ItemTitle: What is the relationship between "receiving the Holy Spirit" and "believing in Jesus'?
Content: What is the relationship between âreceiving the Holy Spiritâ and âbelieving in Jesusâ? The purpose for believing in Jesus is to âbelong to Christ.â â[Y]ou are Christâs; and Christ is Godâsâ (1 Cor 3:23). âFor whoever gives you a cup of water to drink in My name, because you belong to Christ, assuredly, I say to you, he will by no means lose his rewardâ (Mk 9:41). These verses show the importance of belonging to Christ. âNow if anyone does not have the Spirit of Christ, he is not Hisâ (Rom 8:9). To have the Holy Spirit is to be âsealed for the day of redemptionâ (Eph 4:30). The seal of the Holy Spirit means the Lord knows those who are his (2 Tim 2:19). Without the Holy Spiritâs seal, we are like the foolish virgins in Jesusâ parable of the ten virgins who carried lamps without oil. Without oil (symbolic of the Holy Spirit), we cannot shine (manifest Godâs glory). In the last days, the Lord will tell those of us without oil (the Holy Spirit), âI do not know youâ (Mt 25:12). So we must receive the Holy Spirit after we believe in Jesus.

ItemTitle: Do believers need to pray for the Holy Spirit?
Content: Do believers need to pray for the Holy Spirit? While it is the promise of God, receiving the Holy Spirit requires prayer and asking on our part. Luke 11:13 and John 4:10 clearly illustrate this point. The pouring out of the Holy Spirit is also contingent upon the obedience of the Lordâs instructions (Mt 28:20; Acts 5:32). Praying for the Holy Spirit does not deny the authority of God; instead, it is a natural expression of our faith (Mt 15:22-28; Rom 10:14), earnestness (Lk 11:5-8), and persistence (Lk 18:1-8). The Lord Jesus told the disciples of the importance of receiving the Holy Spirit and specifically instructed them not to leave Jerusalem but to wait for the promise of the Holy Spirit (Lk 24:49; Acts 1:4-5, 8). The disciples themselves must have been eager to receive the Holy Spirit; that is why they prayed constantly. The only logical conclusion was that they were praying for the Holy Spirit.

ItemTitle: Who were Jesus" parents?
Content: Who were Jesusâ parents? Jesusâ mother was a virgin named Mary. He was conceived of the Holy Spirit; He is the Son of God. His earthly âfatherâ was Joseph, a carpenter in Galilee who took Mary for his wife (Mt 1:18-25; Lk 1:26-38). Did Jesus have any brothers or sisters? Yes, according to Matthew 13:56, Jesus had four brothers and several sisters. While Jesusâ brothers did not believe in Him during His public ministry (Jn 7:5), they came to believe after His resurrection. James, one of Jesusâ brothers, later became a leader in the church and the author of the epistle that bears his name. Judas, or Jude, is believed to be the author of the epistle of Jude. Yet Jesus also said that whoever does the will of His Father in heaven is His brother, sister, or mother (Mt 12:48-50).

ItemTitle: Where does God live?
Content: Where does God live? God âdwelling in unapproachable light, whom no man has seen or can seeâ (1 Tim 6:16; Job 9:11; 23:3; Ex 33:20; Heb 11:27). The Bible tells us God lives in âheavenâ (Heb 9:24; Ps 123:1; Mt 6:9). Isaiah says God is above all the stars (Isa 14:13), while angels proclaim He is in the highest (Lk 2:14). However, saying God lives in heaven does not mean He is not on earth. God is Spirit and is above a simple material understanding. Being a Spirit, God is in all things (Ps 139:7â8), so we cannot confine God in time or space. As the Bible says, God fills heaven and earth (Jer 23:23â24).

ItemTitle: How should I be baptized?
Content: How should I be baptized? The definition of baptism denotes how and where you should be baptized: immersion in living water. The way a person is baptized carries great spiritual significance. We bow our heads in baptism in the likeness of His death, to signify dying with Christ. Full immersion signifies the complete burial of the old self. In addition to this spiritual significance, baptism in the correct manner actually results in the effect of death and burial of the old self and the resurrection of the new person (Rom 6:3-5; Col 2:12). The baptism of salvation has the spiritual power to cleanse sins. Water baptism is thus different from the traditional ablution of the Jews or proselyte baptism. It is not a mere ritual. It must be performed in the name of the Lord Jesus Christ because a person is baptized into Christ, who forgives sins through baptism (Gal 3:27; Acts 2:38). Ephesians 4:5 points out that there is &quot;one Lord, one faith, one baptism.&quot; All true believers must believe in the same Lord, hold the same faith, and receive the same baptism. It is important to know what the Bible says about how one should be baptized. We also follow the examples that the Lord Jesus and the disciples set.

ItemTitle: Did Jesus die for Jews (God's chosen people) or all people?
Content: Did Jesus die for Jews (Godâs chosen people) or all people? Jesus died for the sins of the whole world (1 Jn 2:2). He was delivered to die on a tree for our sins (1 Pet 2:24), and becoming a curse for us (Gal 3:13â14). Isaiah clearly prophesied, âSurely he has borne our griefs and carried our sorrows; yet we esteemed him stricken, smitten by God, and afflicted. But he was wounded for our transgressions, he was bruised for our iniquities; upon him was the chastisement that made us whole, and by his stripes we are healedâ (Isa 53:4â5). While the Bible is often directed towards Godâs people Israel and the Jews, the Bible makes it clear Jesus died to save the whole world of sinners, which includes everyone. Jesusâ death is intimately related to every personâs salvation. So let us humbly accept Jesus as our personal Savior.

ItemTitle: What important messages are found in the gospel?
Content: What important messages are found in the gospel? The gospel tells that God sent His one and only Son, Jesus Christ, into the world. Jesus was God Himself, but He was a âson?in the sense God became flesh. âSon of Man?emphasizes Jesus?humanity. Yet, Jesus was the Savior of His people. Jesus?salvation succeeds in five ways as a source of our salvation. The following has been done for us, and this is at the heart of Jesus?gospel: Christ was born for us. âFor there is born to you this day in the city of David a Savior, who is Christ the Lord"(Lk 2:11). Christ died for us. âChrist died for our sins according to the Scriptures"(1 Cor 15:3; Rom 5:8). Christ resurrected for us. He was âwas raised because of our justification"(Rom 4:25). Christ ascended into heaven for us. âI go to prepare a place for you" (Jn 14:2?). Christ will come again for us. He will âappear a second time, apart from sin, for salvation" (Heb 9:28). These five points are basic Christian beliefs and are guiding principles out of which come all the derivatives of the gospel. However, donât confuse this with a belief that these are the only things we need to know for salvation. The Bible is a big book with lots of things to learn about salvation.

ItemTitle: Is there a common prayer in the Bible for all believers?
Content: Is there a common prayer in the Bible for all believers? Yes. When Jesusâ disciples asked Jesus how to pray, Jesus taught the disciples what we call the &quot;Lordâs Prayer.&quot; Every believer should learn the Lordâs Prayer by heart. The Lord taught, &quot;In this manner, therefore, pray: Our Father in heaven, hallowed be Your name. Your kingdom come. Your will be done on earth as it is in heaven. Give us this day our daily bread. And forgive us our debts, as we forgive our debtors. And do not lead us into temptation, but deliver us from the evil one. For Yours is the kingdom and the power and the glory forever. Amen&quot; (Mt 6:9â13).

ItemTitle: How can we know God exists?
Content: How can we know God exists? How can we know God exists? From Creation If something exists, it has either 1) always existed, 2) been created by something that always existed, or 3) created itself. We know from evidence that the universe has not always existed. We also know that it is impossible for something finite to create itself. It would have to exist in order to create; but how can something be and not be at the same time? Therefore, the only option remaining is the universe was created by something that has always existed, has infinite might and eternal life. The Bible tells us that "since the creation of the world His invisible attributes are clearly seen, being understood by the things that are made, even His eternal power and Godhead" (Rom 1:20). When we see a tree, we realize that there was once a seed from which it grew. When we see a child, we recognize that there were parents that gave birth to the child. When we consider the universe, we know there must be a source for its being: Existence is like a gift given from cause to effect. If there is no one who has the gift, the gift cannot be passed down the chain of receivers, however long or short the chain may be... If there is no God who has existence by His own eternal nature, then the gift of existence cannot be passed down the chain of creatures and we can never get it. But we do get it; we exist. Therefore there must exist a God: an Uncaused Being.&#185; We are able to exist today because there are complex forces, systems and structures working in the universe, keeping it in order. The earth sustains life because it is located at just the right distance from the sun, between the thermally uninhabitable limits of the boiling and freezing points of water. We live because each cell of our bodies possesses about 80,000 genes that enable the trillions of cells we have to function and communicate with each other. From the macro world to the micro, we see both precision and complexity, but above all, purpose, in existence. Nudge the earth a little off its path of orbit, and the temperature would cause all of life to die; alter or remove a gene, and the whole body may be destroyed. Such explicit design declares the existence of an intelligent creator. From His Word God has revealed His existence and His plans for humankind through His own word. The existence of the Bible and its lasting influence over thousands of years attest to something greater than the invention of man. Indeed, how could over forty authors, from peasants to kings, statesmen to fishermen, and over a span of forty generations have presented such a consistent image of God and message of His divine plan unless His existence were real? Accumulated evidence has demonstrated the truth of the Word: not only through corroborating archaeological findings&#178;, but also through the fulfillment of over 600 specific, biblical prophecies through the ages&#179; and its ultimate materialization in Jesus Christ (Jn 1:1,14). From Human Consciousness God exists because we know and experience Him. The book of Romans tells us that humans "knew God" but "suppress the truth in unrighteousness" (Rom 1:21,18). And yet an underlying moral consciousness, a universal sense of right and wrong, persists within us, testifying to that ultimate source of justice. Though laws may vary across boundaries and "values" are subjective, there are universally accepted notions of how one ought (e.g. with honor, kindness) or ought not (e.g. murder, rape, lie) to behave that have prevailed through history and across cultural boundaries. Fundamentally, or at the very least, we recognize the obligation to obey our conscience&#151an obligation that neither arises from nature nor ourselves, nor society, for none of the three can fully "impose" that obligation on us. The only source for the absolute moral obligation to obey our conscience is God. The universal desire, found among people in every age and culture, to seek out and worship God also affirms his existence. Why would the desire exist if there were no real object for it? We would not feel hunger or thirst unless food and water existed. As C.S. Lewis argued in Mere Christianity, "If I find in myself a desire which no experience in this world can satisfy, the most probable explanation is that I was made for another world." A person might win a million dollars, achieve a certain level of fame, or gain the affection of others, but still seek something better that he knows exists "out there." The fulfillment, the perfect goodness, the complete love we long for truly exists; the delusion occurs when we fail to recognize we are really missing God. From Experience Our knowledge of God, however, is not only based on inference. We can know he exists through experience. God does directly intervene in our lives, as testimony reveals. When we hear about a person healed from a fatal illness, or a baby found sleeping, cradled in the limb of a tree, after a tornado, we recognize that certain incidents cannot be rationally explained. There must be someone beyond our "ordinary," "rational" world who has control over it: there must be God. When we practice Godâs word, we will see the results. When we pray, as he instructed us, God listens and answers our prayers, even in miraculous ways. If we pray for the Holy Spirit, we will receive it, as many believers can testify&#151;truly experiencing the power and joy in the spirit as the Bible describes. Moreover, when we receive the Holy Spirit, we experience the guiding presence of God daily (Ezek 36:27). Peter Kreeft and Ronald K. Tacelli, Handbook of Christian Apologetics (Downers Grove, IL: InterVarsity Press, 1994), 51. For a measured look at current archaeological evidence, see Jeffery L. Sheler, "Is the Bible true?" U.S. News and World Report (October 25, 1999). For a detailed discussion of biblical prophecy and fulfillment, see Josh McDowell, Evidence that Demands a Verdict , vol.1 (Nashville: Thomas Nelson Publishers, 1979) 265-323.

ItemTitle: How does salvation benefit me?
Content: How does salvation benefit me? Salvation saves us from the spiritual darkness and death (Lk 1:79; 19:10; Heb 9:27; Jas 5:20). Salvation rescues us from the slavery, oppression, and binding force of sin (Rom 6:17â18; Lk 1:74). Salvation justifies and saves us from the condemnation of sin (Jude 23; Rom 5:16). Salvation is intimately related to Godâs calling to us (2 Tim 1:9; 1 Pet 5:10; Eph 1:18). Salvation leads us to justification and redemption (Rom 3:24; Tit 3:7). Salvation gives us eternal life through Jesus Christ (Rom 5:21; 6:23; Acts 11:18). Salvation allows us to receive Godâs glory (Rom 5:2; Heb 2:9â10; Rom 8:30; 1 Pet 5:10).

ItemTitle: How did death come into this world?
Content: How did death come into this world? God told the first man, Adam, that he and Eve could not eat the fruit of the tree of the knowledge of good and evil, or else they would die. Adam and Eve chose instead to listen to Satan, the tempter. They disobeyed Godâs specific command, so sin entered the world, and death with it (Rom 5:12). Death and sin go hand in hand: the cause of death is sin (Rom 6:23). Sin separates us from God, who is holy. Apart from Him who is the source of life, we no longer have His eternal life in us. Our bodies are mortal, and our spirits, because of sin, are condemned to eternal death.

ItemTitle: How did Jesus die?
Content: How did Jesus die? Jesus died by crucifixion, a brutal form of capital punishment by the Romans. Jesus spoke his last words on the cross, saying, âIt is finished,â meaning his work was accomplished. In the spiritual realm, finishing his work on earth meant Godâs work was guaranteed. In the spiritual realm there is no space and time as we understand it. So Jesus bowed his head and gave up his spirit (Jn 19:30). One of the soldiers pierced Jesusâ side with a spear, bringing a sudden flow of blood and water (Jn 19:34). The blood and water opened up the fountain for the forgiveness of sins. In Christian terms, those who are baptized can be forgiven of their sins through Jesusâ blood.

ItemTitle: What is the role of the members?
Content: What is the role of the members? Like a family, the church provides the church provides for the spiritual needs of her members. The Holy Spirit distributes various gifts and abilities to the members so that they may serve and encourage one another (1 Cor 12:4-11). As members of the family, we need to work together using our God-given abilities to help each other grow. The spirit of unity and mutual support is the guiding principle of the church. Having the love and grace of our Lord as our common bond, we share together the joy, peace, and strength in Christ.

ItemTitle: Where was Jesus born and where did he grow up?
Content: Where was Jesus born and where did he grow up? Jesus was born in Bethlehem of Judah (Lk 2:4), which is the city of David. Joseph and Mary left Nazareth and went to Bethlehem to be registered in a Roman census. Later, Jesusâ parents returned to Nazareth, where Jesus grew up (Mt 2:23). Nazareth was a small city in Galilee. Nazareth lay on a southeastern slope of a valley. On three sides of the small city were mountains at least 500 feet above the valley. South of Nazareth was the great plain of Esdraelon, with the Sea of Galilee to the east. In the valley, there were gardens full of flowers and trees. Just outside the city, cypress trees surrounded the homes of the village people. The Nazarene scene was beautiful through all four seasons.

ItemTitle: Does this mean that you should wait a while after baptism (till after your feet have become "dirtied') to receive footwashing?
Content: Does this mean that you should wait a while after baptism (till after your feet have become âdirtiedâ) to receive footwashing? Just as there is no reason to put off baptism after you have fully realized your sins and the need for Jesus Christ to save you with His cleansing blood, there should be no reason to put off footwashing. Like baptism, footwashing is a sacrament empowered with Godâs grace. By following the Lordâs command, we share in His grace. As Jesus said, âIf you know these things, blessed are you if you do themâ (Jn 13:17). By receiving footwashing, we furthermore commit ourselves to following His footsteps, and participating in His divine nature. We accept the invitation to have a part in Him, and in His heavenly kingdom.

ItemTitle: Who is the head of the church?
Content: Who is the head of the church? Jesus Christ is the âhead of the church.â Out of His love for the church, He gave His own life for her. So the church must submit to Christ in everything. She must follow Christâs command and do only what Christ would do, and speak what Christ would speak (Eph 5:23-24).

ItemTitle: In whose name should we pray?
Content: In whose name should we pray? At the beginning and end of each prayer we should say âIn the name of the Lord Jesus I prayâ (cf. Jn 14:13â14), for Jesusâ name was given by God (Jn 17:11â12). Jesus is Godâs name. Other ânamesâ were actually more like titles than names (e.g., memorial names like âI AM WHO I AMâ). Isaiah describes Jesus as, âWonderful Counselor, Mighty God, Everlasting Father, Prince of Peaceâ (Isa 9:6). Jesus said, â[W]hatever you ask the Father in my name, he may give it to youâ (Jn 15:16). We should pray in Jesusâ name, for it is our salvation (Acts 4:12).

ItemTitle: What are the two dimensions of salvation?
Content: What are the two dimensions of salvation? The two dimensions of salvation are: Salvation from and forgiveness of our sins (Mt 1:21; Lk 1:77; Jn 1:29; Acts 5:31). Salvation helps us resolve the problem of sinâa problem we cannot resolve by ourselves. This is exactly why we need to be saved. If we could resolve the problem of our sins ourselves we wouldnât need saving! The Bible says, âIn him [Jesus] we have redemption through his blood, the forgiveness of our sins, according to the riches of his graceâ (Eph 1:7). To those blessed by God, God does not impute their sins (Rom 4:8); instead, God credits the blessed with righteousness apart from any works (Rom 4:6). God justifies us freely, he does not justify us to repay us for something we did for him (Rom 4:4). God doesnât need anything, nor could we give him anything, for all things are his. The gift of abundant and, ultimately, eternal life (Jn 3:16; Jn 5:40; Jn 10:10, 28). Salvation resolves the result of sinâdeath. Human beings, left alone in sin, will ultimately die, both physically and spiritually. But whoever believes in the Son (Jesus Christ) has eternal life (Jn 3:36). For Jesusâ believers have crossed over from death to life (Jn 5:24). Grace reigns through righteousness to bring life through Jesus Christ our Lord (Rom 5:21). So salvation ultimately gives us eternal life.

ItemTitle: Should spiritual tongues be intelligible?
Content: Should spiritual tongues be intelligible? The disciples did not actually speak in foreign languages. But God opened the ears of the Jews so that they heard the disciples speaking in their own languages (Acts 2:8,11). Ordinarily if several people speak in more than two languages at once, no one else can make out what is being said. On the day of Pentecost, however, 120 people all spoke in tongues. Jews from about 15 language groups were able to understand that they were âspeaking the wonderful works of Godâ in their own tongues (Acts 2:8-11). The tongues were not intelligible to everyone in the crowd. While the devout Jews understood the tongues, others thought the disciples had too much wine (Acts 2:13). If the disciples were indeed speaking foreign languages, why then did only the devout Jews understand what was being said? And why did the ungodly think the disciples were drunk? God intended to save the devout Jews and so allowed them to understand the tongues. Consequently, many believed and were baptized into Christ (Acts 2:37-41). The mockers, on the other hand, could not understand.

ItemTitle: Didn't Jesus clearly instruct His disciples to baptize "in the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Spirit" in Matthew 28:19?
Content: Didn't Jesus clearly instruct His disciples to baptize "in the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Spirit" in Matthew 28:19? We know that the Lord's words in Matthew 28 were not a formula to be recited, since the disciples always baptized and instructed people to be baptized in the name of the Lord Jesus (Acts 2:38; 8:16; 10:48; 19:5). &quot;In the name of&quot; is not just a recitation, but indicates the authority and power of the risen Christ (Phil 2:10-11). It is in Jesus that we can have the forgiveness of sins during baptism (Col 1:14). Because it is into Christ that we are baptized (Gal 3:27), the baptismal candidate must believe the Lord Jesus is his Lord and Savior and determine to live for Christ all his life. Instead of saying &quot;in Jesus' name,&quot; Jesus said &quot;in the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Spirit&quot; to show that all authority that belonged to God had been given to Him. &quot;Father,&quot; &quot;Son,&quot; or &quot;the Holy Spirit&quot; are not names. They are titles. The name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Spirit is &quot;Jesus&quot; (Jn 5:43; 17:11; 14:26), and there is only one name (singular). There is no other name under heaven given to men by which we must be saved than the the name of Jesus Christ (Acts 4:10, 12). Only by the name of Jesus is a person cleansed of sin during baptism (Acts 2:38; 10:43).

ItemTitle: How can footwashing be a lesson of servitude and humility?
Content: How can footwashing be a lesson of servitude and humility? In the ancient Jewish and Greco-Roman world, the washing of feet was often the lowest form of servitude, a task delegated to slaves. But Jesus, the glorious king of heaven, knelt down and washed the feet of sinners. Most amazing of all, he even washed the feet of Judas, His betrayer. Just as the Master bowed down to serve, we as His disciples must bow down to serve othersâeven our enemies.

ItemTitle: I was baptized in the name of the Father, Son and Holy Spirit. Why must I be baptized in the name of Jesus Christ?
Content: I was baptized in the name of the Father, Son and Holy Spirit. Why must I be baptized in the name of Jesus Christ? âFather,â or âSon,â or âthe Holy Spiritâ are not names. They are titles. The name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Spirit is âJesusâ (Jn 5:43; 17:11; 14:26), and there is only one name (singular). The name âJesusâ carries authority and honor (Phil 2:9-11). In the name of the Lord Jesus, baptism has the power to heal and make new. God has also manifested His power when believers cast out demons in the name of the Lord Jesus. But it is not merely the recitation of the name that makes baptism effective or drives away evil spirits. It is the presence of the Holy Spirit and the promise of God that manifests Godâs power in Jesusâ name. The name of Jesus Christ is the only one under heaven given to men by which we must be saved (Acts 4:10,12). The disciples always baptized or instructed the people to be baptized in the name of the Lord Jesus (Acts 2:38; 8:16; 10:48; 19:5). In Acts 19:4-5, the believers were re-baptized âin the name of the Lord Jesus.â Only through the name of Jesus is a personâs sin cleansed during baptism (Acts 2:38; 10:43).

ItemTitle: Aren't all Christian churches and denominations members of the body of Christ? Each church has its unique gift (i.e. emphasis on certain teachings). Joined together, don't they make up the body of Christ described in Ephesians 4:16?
Content: Arenât all Christian churches and denominations members of the body of Christ? Each church has its unique gift (i.e. emphasis on certain teachings). Joined together, donât they make up the body of Christ described in Ephesians 4:16? There is no biblical support to show that different churches are members of the body of Christ. Rather the believers are members of Christâs body (Eph 4:12) and the body is the church (singular; Eph 1:22-23: 5:23; Col 1:24). The church holds only one faith (Eph 4:5). Today different churches proclaim different or even conflicting beliefs about salvation. They cannot be of the same body. The church believes in one baptism (Eph 4:5). Many churches, however, disagree on the importance, efficacy, and mode of baptism. So they cannot be of the same body. The church receives only one Spirit (the Holy Spirit; Eph 4:4; 1Cor 12:13). Many churches do not even believe that believers need to pray for the Holy Spirit, with speaking in tongues as the evidence. How can they be of the same body with the true church, where believers pray for and receive the promised Holy Spirit? For the church to unite and become one, members of different denominations must remove their differences in faith, become one under the name of Jesus (Jn 17:11), and unite in the Holy Spirit (Eph 4:3-4; 1Cor 12:13) and in truth (i.e. common faith; Eph 4:5).

ItemTitle: What is the nature and character of the Holy Spirit?
Content: What is the nature and character of the Holy Spirit? Some people think the Holy Spirit is like Godâs breath. While it is true that the words spirit and breath are alike in the Hebrew language, thinking of the Spirit in terms of Godâs breath doesnât reveal Godâs full divine character. Breath just seems so inanimate and impersonal compared to a living character. The Bible shows the Holy Spirit has divine character. The Spirit searches all things (1 Cor 2:10); he has his own will (Rom 8:27; 1 Cor 12:11); he is loving (Rom 15:30); he gives grace (Heb 10:20); he can be grieved (Eph 4:30); he instructs (Neh 9:20); he can speak (Acts 8:29); he prevents (Acts 16:6â7); he commands (Acts 13:2, 4; Isa 48:16); he establishes ministry (Acts 20:28); he testifies (1 Jn 5:7); and he reveals (Eph 3:5). All these actions show the Holy Spirit has divine character.

ItemTitle: What types of sin are there?
Content: What types of sin are there? To sin is to miss the mark. When we fall short of Godâs intention for us, then we sin. God has set out His intentions clearly in the Bible; His fundamental requirements are the Ten Commandments. And the essence of those 10 commandments can be distilled to these two: You shall love the Lord your God with all your heart, soul and mind. You shall love your neighbor as yourself. (Mt 22:37-49) When we fail to do so, then we sin. The Bible tells us we must put to death these sins: fornication, uncleanness, passion, evil desire, covetousness, anger, malice, blasphemy, filthy language, lying (Col 3:5-9; see also 1 Cor 6:9-10; Gal 5:19-21; Eph 5:3-7). Following the desires of our flesh will lead us to these sins. Failure to do the good we know we should do is also sin (Jas 4:17; known as âsin of omissionâ). The good we know we should do is also derived from the two essential commandments. We need to be holy, faithful, merciful, kind, patient; meek and humble; forbearing and forgiving; loving to the point of sacrifice.

ItemTitle: Why doesn't the Bible record the disciples washing others" feet?
Content: Why doesnât the Bible record the disciples washing othersâ feet? John carefully recorded not only the act that Jesus performed, but the instructions and spiritual teachings that He imparted to the disciples during the sacrament of footwashing. All of the Lordâs commandments need to be kept. Not a single commandment can be neglected, regardless of how many times it is mentioned in the Bible (Mt 5:18-19; Rev 22:19). We can thus be sure that although there is no biblical record of the disciples performing the sacrament, they would have obeyed Jesusâ direct instruction to them.

ItemTitle: Isn't keeping the Sabbath a Jewish tradition?
Content: Isnât keeping the Sabbath a Jewish tradition? The Sabbath was instituted in the very beginning (Gen 2:1-3; Ex 20:11), before the nation of Israel existed. There was no death, no religion, no covenant, no law, no nation, no Jew or Gentile and, of course, no racial distinction. Jesus said the âSabbath was made for manâ (Mk 2:27)ânot only for the Jews. The benefits and privileges of receiving rest, blessings, and sanctification from observing the seventh-day Sabbath are given to all mankind. Honoring the Sabbath day is the fourth of the Ten Commandments. Even though they were first entrusted to the chosen people of the Old Testament, Godâs commands are passed on to the chosen people of the New Testament (see Acts 7:38). The Ten Commandments have never been abolished; they still need to be kept by Christians today (Lk 18:18-20; 1 Cor 7:19; 1 Jn 5:2-3; Rev 14:12). Isaiahâs prophecy that foreigners will keep the Sabbath further confirms that Gentile believers in the New Testament will keep Godâs Sabbath (Isa 56:6-7). So Sabbath observance isnât just limited to the Israelite nation.

ItemTitle: Isn't baptism just a public declaration of your faith in Jesus and membership in a church?
Content: Isnât baptism just a public declaration of your faith in Jesus and membership in a church? Baptism is not simply a public expression of salvation. The Bible makes it clear that baptism is for the forgiveness of sins (Acts 22:16; 2:38). We receive Godâs salvation through baptism (1 Pet 3:20-21; Col 2:11-12; Rom 6:3-4; Gal 3:26-27).

ItemTitle: Why does God allow people to sin?
Content: Why does God allow people to sin? God did not create a world of robots to mechanically serve His purposes. He created the universe to manifest His divine nature of love. But true love can only exist with freedom, just as true righteousness can only exist with freedom. We cannot truly love if we are forced to do so against our will; we cannot be morally perfect if we do not choose to do good out of our own volition. To protect the well being of His creation, God established laws for us to obey. God shows us what is good: âto do justly, to love mercy, and to walk humblyâ with Him (Mic 6:8). His commandments also teach us the consequences of our choices (Rom 5:13). But He permits us the freedom to do as we will. He wants human beings to love Him and obey His commands out of our own volition, not out of compulsion.

ItemTitle: Salvation is by grace through faith, not by works (Ephesians 2:8,9). Aren't sacraments of works, not of faith?
Content: Salvation is by grace through faith, not by works (Ephesians 2:8,9).
